hints.content:
An $\blueE{\text{even}}$ number is a number that can be split into $2$ equal groups.

We find $\blueE{\text{even}}$ numbers by making sure every object in the group has a pair.

![](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/9d50cd961bb1ee962eb60cc708a5e737e9d4486c)

Examples of $\blueE{\text{even}}$ numbers are $\blueE2, \blueE4,\blueE6, \blueE8, \blueE{10},  . .  .$

An $\maroonD{\text{odd}}$ number **cannot** be split into $2$ equal groups. 

We find $\maroonD{\text{odd}}$ numbers by trying to pair objects and finding there is **not** always a pair.

![](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/10c3af09ebfcd0c6d05b4edd219f33894cc4d8b9)

Examples of $\maroonD{\text{odd}}$ numbers are $\maroonD1, \maroonD3, \maroonD5, \maroonD7, \maroonD9, . . . $

In this image, there are $\blueE{14}$ mice.

![](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/19bf0ece216960e5dfca6ffb09f4240008ffeaa2)

Each mouse has a pair, so there are an even number of mice.

In this image, there are $\maroonD{17}$ sheep.

![](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/73c1387e1ba9f50f9864b3aee627578f82357c90)

Each sheep does **not** have a pair, so there are an odd number of sheep.

In this image, there are $\blueE{12}$ ice cream cones.

![](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/2447fe9490ace43484c0a7c11438b31a8e416362)

Each ice cream cone has a pair, so there are an even number of ice cream cones.

Here is the completed table:

Image | Even/Odd
- | - | -
![](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/c0456a89ef030afc2932e22a85893608e99cf79d)| **Even**
![](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/cfc1da2a720308b0c51b56d2cc0c9f2080a4f5e1) | **Odd**
![](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/72cefed0a81e4648be0fbe08ea5a562540b2ff08)  | **Even**

question.content:
